Quiz.Explanation: An H-bridge allows current to flow in both directions through a motor, enabling forward and reverse motion!
Quiz.Question: What does an H-bridge allow a motor to do?

SafetyNotes: Motor may get warm during operation

Instructions.Description: Place the L293D IC on breadboard, noting the notch orientation.
Instructions.Title: Insert H-Bridge IC

Instructions.Description: Connect VCC (pin 16) to 9V and GND (pins 4,5,12,13) to ground.
Instructions.Title: Wire Power Connections

Instructions.Description: Connect motor terminals to output pins 3 and 6 of the IC.
Instructions.Title: Connect Motor

Instructions.Description: Connect pins 2 and 7 to control switches for direction control.
Instructions.Title: Wire Control Inputs

Instructions.Description: Connect pin 1 (enable) to positive to activate motor driver.
Instructions.Title: Enable Motor

Instructions.Description: Use switches to make motor spin forward and reverse.
Instructions.Title: Test Directions

Title: H-Bridge Motor Control
LearningObjectives: Understand current flow in motor circuits
FunFact: H-bridges are used in everything from toy cars to electric vehicles and industrial robots!

Quiz.Explanation: The L293D has two H-bridges, allowing it to control two DC motors independently!
Quiz.Question: How many motors can a single L293D IC control?

SafetyNotes: Both motors share same power supply

Instructions.Description: Place L293D on breadboard with proper orientation.
Instructions.Title: Setup IC

Instructions.Description: Connect VCC and all GND pins as in previous level.
Instructions.Title: Power the IC

Instructions.Description: Wire first motor to output pins 3 and 6 (channel 1).
Instructions.Title: Connect Motor A

Instructions.Description: Wire second motor to output pins 11 and 14 (channel 2).
Instructions.Title: Connect Motor B

Instructions.Description: Connect switches to pins 2 and 7 for first motor direction.
Instructions.Title: Wire Controls for Motor A

Instructions.Description: Connect switches to pins 10 and 15 for second motor direction.
Instructions.Title: Wire Controls for Motor B

Instructions.Description: Connect pins 1 and 9 (enable pins) to positive.
Instructions.Title: Enable Both Motors

Instructions.Description: Control each motor separately to verify independent operation.
Instructions.Title: Test Independence
Instructions.Tip: Try making them spin in opposite directions!

Title: Dual Motor Coordination
FunFact: Robot vehicles use dual motor control to steer by varying the speed and direction of left and right motors!

Quiz.Explanation: The ratio is 30:10 or 3:1, meaning the output gear turns 3 times slower but with 3 times more torque!
Quiz.Question: If a 10-tooth gear drives a 30-tooth gear, what is the gear ratio?

SafetyNotes: Keep fingers away from rotating gears

Instructions.Description: Secure motor to mounting board with shaft accessible.
Instructions.Title: Mount Motor

Instructions.Description: Fix the small gear (driver) onto the motor shaft.
Instructions.Title: Attach Small Gear

Instructions.Description: Mount large gear on axle so teeth mesh with small gear.
Instructions.Title: Position Large Gear
Instructions.Tip: Gears should touch lightly but not bind!

Instructions.Description: Attach pointer flags to both gears to visualize rotation.
Instructions.Title: Add Pointer

Instructions.Description: Connect motor to battery through switch.
Instructions.Title: Wire Motor Circuit

Instructions.Description: Turn on motor and count rotations. Small gear spins faster!
Instructions.Title: Test Gear Ratio

Instructions.Description: Count teeth on each gear and divide large by small.
Instructions.Title: Calculate Ratio
Instructions.Tip: A 2:1 ratio means driver turns twice per output turn!

Title: Gear Systems
LearningObjectives: Understand gear ratios and mechanical advantage
FunFact: Bicycle gears work the same way - lower gears provide more torque for climbing hills, while higher gears give more speed!

Quiz.Explanation: Encoders track motor rotation by counting pulses, which tells us both the position and speed of the motor!
Quiz.Question: What does a motor encoder measure?

Instructions.Description: Mount slotted disk securely to motor shaft.
Instructions.Title: Attach Encoder Disk

Instructions.Description: Place IR LED on one side of disk with proper current-limiting resistor.
Instructions.Title: Position IR LED

Instructions.Description: Mount phototransistor opposite the IR LED to detect light.
Instructions.Title: Position Phototransistor
Instructions.Tip: Align sensor pair with disk slots!

Instructions.Description: Connect phototransistor with pull-up resistor to detect pulses.
Instructions.Title: Wire Sensor Circuit

Instructions.Description: Wire indicator LED to phototransistor output to visualize pulses.
Instructions.Title: Connect Indicator LED

Instructions.Description: Connect motor to power supply through switch.
Instructions.Title: Wire Motor

Instructions.Description: Run motor and watch indicator LED blink as disk rotates.
Instructions.Title: Test Encoder

Instructions.Description: Count LED blinks in 10 seconds to measure motor speed.
Instructions.Title: Count Pulses

Title: Motor Encoder Feedback
FunFact: Computer mice use optical encoders to track movement. Modern optical mice sense thousands of position changes per second!

Quiz.Explanation: Unlike standard servos limited to 180° rotation, continuous rotation servos can spin freely in either direction at variable speeds!
Quiz.Question: What makes a continuous rotation servo different from a standard servo?

Instructions.Description: Wire 555 IC in astable mode on breadboard.
Instructions.Title: Setup 555 Timer

Instructions.Description: Connect potentiometer to adjust 555 duty cycle.
Instructions.Title: Add Potentiometer

Instructions.Description: Connect resistors and capacitor for ~50Hz PWM output.
Instructions.Title: Wire Timing Components

Instructions.Description: Wire servo red wire to +6V and brown/black to ground.
Instructions.Title: Connect Servo Power

Instructions.Description: Connect 555 output (pin 3) to servo signal wire (orange/yellow).
Instructions.Title: Connect Control Signal

Instructions.Description: Adjust potentiometer to change servo speed and direction.
Instructions.Title: Test Speed Control

Title: Continuous Rotation Servo
FunFact: Continuous rotation servos are popular in small robots because they provide precise speed control without needing separate motor drivers!

Quiz.Explanation: Hall effect sensors detect magnetic fields, making them perfect for sensing the position and speed of rotating magnets!
Quiz.Question: What does a Hall effect sensor detect?

SafetyNotes: Mount magnet securely to avoid flying off
Keep magnet away from electronics until mounted

Instructions.Description: Secure cardboard disk to motor shaft.
Instructions.Title: Attach Disk to Motor

Instructions.Description: Tape small magnet to edge of rotating disk.
Instructions.Title: Mount Magnet

Instructions.Description: Mount Hall effect sensor close to disk edge path.
Instructions.Title: Position Hall Sensor
Instructions.Tip: Sensor should be 1-3mm from magnet path!

Instructions.Description: Connect sensor VCC, GND, and output with pull-up resistor.
Instructions.Title: Wire Hall Sensor

Instructions.Description: Wire three LEDs in series as speed visualization.
Instructions.Title: Create LED Indicator

Instructions.Description: Wire motor with potentiometer for variable speed control.
Instructions.Title: Connect Motor Circuit

Instructions.Description: Start motor and verify Hall sensor detects magnet each revolution.
Instructions.Title: Test Sensor

Instructions.Description: Count pulses per minute to calculate RPM.
Instructions.Title: Measure Speed

Title: Motor Speed Sensors
FunFact: Your car's speedometer uses a Hall effect sensor to measure wheel rotation and calculate your speed!

Quiz.Explanation: Differential steering works by running motors at different speeds or directions - faster right motor makes the car turn left!
Quiz.Question: How does a two-motor car turn?

SafetyNotes: Test circuits before installing in chassis
Keep wires away from moving parts

Instructions.Description: Cut and assemble car body from cardboard or kit parts.
Instructions.Title: Build Chassis

Instructions.Description: Attach both motors to rear of chassis with proper alignment.
Instructions.Title: Mount Motors

Instructions.Description: Attach wheels to motor shafts, ensuring good grip.
Instructions.Title: Install Drive Wheels
Instructions.Tip: Add rubber bands to wheels for better traction!

Instructions.Description: Install front wheels on axles that spin freely.
Instructions.Title: Add Free Wheels

Instructions.Description: Connect L293D IC circuit on breadboard.
Instructions.Title: Wire Motor Driver

Instructions.Description: Wire both motors to IC outputs for independent control.
Instructions.Title: Connect Motors

Instructions.Description: Mount switches for controlling direction of each motor.
Instructions.Title: Add Control Switches

Instructions.Description: Mount battery securely in center of chassis for balance.
Instructions.Title: Install Battery

Instructions.Description: Test forward, reverse, left turn, and right turn movements.
Instructions.Title: Test Drive

Instructions.Description: Adjust wheel alignment and motor speeds for straight driving.
Instructions.Title: Fine-tune
Instructions.Tip: If car pulls to one side, check motor speeds!

Title: Build a Moving Car
FunFact: The first radio-controlled car was built in 1966. Today's RC cars can reach speeds over 200 mph!

Quiz.Explanation: Gears provide mechanical advantage, trading speed for torque. This allows a small motor to lift much heavier loads!
Options: To increase torque for heavier loads
Quiz.Question: Why might you add gears to a crane's lifting motor?

SafetyNotes: Build stable base to prevent tipping
Keep hands away from moving parts

Instructions.Description: Construct stable platform for crane base with rotation mechanism.
Instructions.Title: Build Base

Instructions.Description: Build crane arm from dowels, ensuring strength for load.
Instructions.Title: Construct Boom

Instructions.Description: Mount first motor at base for 360° crane rotation.
Instructions.Title: Install Rotation Motor

Instructions.Description: Mount second motor with spool for winding lifting cable.
Instructions.Title: Install Lift Motor
Instructions.Tip: Add gearing for more lifting power!

Instructions.Description: Mount servo at boom end to control hook opening/closing.
Instructions.Title: Add Servo Hook

Instructions.Description: Thread cable through boom and attach to hook mechanism.
Instructions.Title: String Lifting System

Instructions.Description: Build dual motor control circuit on breadboard.
Instructions.Title: Wire Motor Driver

Instructions.Description: Build 555 timer circuit for servo position control.
Instructions.Title: Wire Servo Control

Instructions.Description: Wire rotation motor, lift motor, and servo to controllers.
Instructions.Title: Connect All Motors

Instructions.Description: Mount switches and potentiometers for operator control.
Instructions.Title: Add Control Interface

Instructions.Description: Practice rotating, lifting, and hook operations separately.
Instructions.Title: Test Operations
Instructions.Tip: Master each function before combining them!

AdditionalMaterials: Wooden dowels or straws for boom
Hook or small container for load
Bearing or lazy susan for rotation
Title: Build a Crane
LearningObjectives: Coordinate multiple motors for complex motion
FunFact: The world's largest crane can lift 20,000 tons - equivalent to about 3,000 elephants!

Quiz.Explanation: You need at least 3 servos: one for X-axis, one for Y-axis positioning, and one to lift the pen up and down for drawing control!
Quiz.Question: How many servos minimum are needed for a 2D drawing machine?

Instructions.Description: Create stable base with area for paper (20cm x 20cm recommended).
Instructions.Title: Build Base Frame

Instructions.Description: Install first servo for horizontal (X) movement control.
Instructions.Title: Mount X-Axis Servo

Instructions.Description: Attach arm to X servo that extends across paper width.
Instructions.Title: Build X-Axis Arm

Instructions.Description: Install second servo on X arm for vertical (Y) movement.
Instructions.Title: Mount Y-Axis Servo
Instructions.Tip: Mount Y servo on sliding carriage!

Instructions.Description: Create holder that positions pen tip just above paper.
Instructions.Title: Build Pen Holder

Instructions.Description: Mount mini servo to raise and lower pen for drawing control.
Instructions.Title: Add Pen Lift Servo

Instructions.Description: Build 555 timer circuit with pot for X-axis servo control.
Instructions.Title: Wire X-Axis Control

Instructions.Description: Build second 555 circuit with pot for Y-axis servo control.
Instructions.Title: Wire Y-Axis Control

Instructions.Description: Connect button to control pen lift servo position.
Instructions.Title: Wire Pen Lift

Instructions.Description: Adjust servo ranges to cover full paper area without collisions.
Instructions.Title: Calibrate Movement

Instructions.Description: Practice drawing lines, shapes, and patterns!
Instructions.Title: Test Drawing
Instructions.Tip: Start with simple shapes before complex drawings!

AdditionalMaterials: Wooden sticks or straws for arms
Title: Build a Drawing Machine
FunFact: Modern pen plotters like this were used in the 1980s for computer graphics. Today, similar X-Y systems control 3D printers and laser cutters!

Quiz.Explanation: Limit switches detect when the curtain reaches fully open or closed positions and stop the motor, preventing damage from over-extension!
Options: They prevent motor damage by stopping at end positions
Quiz.Question: Why are limit switches important in an automated curtain system?

SafetyNotes: Test system with light loads first
Ensure limit switches stop motor reliably
Keep cords away from motor mechanism

Instructions.Description: Measure curtain width and determine mounting locations.
Instructions.Title: Plan Installation

Instructions.Description: Mount curtain rod with pulleys at both ends.
Instructions.Title: Install Rod System

Instructions.Description: Secure geared motor with cord spool at one end of rod.
Instructions.Title: Mount Motor Unit
Instructions.Tip: Use a gearbox for more pulling power!

Instructions.Description: Thread cord through pulleys, attaching to curtain and motor spool.
Instructions.Title: String Pulling Cord

Instructions.Description: Mount switches at fully-open and fully-closed positions.
Instructions.Title: Install Limit Switches

Instructions.Description: Wire H-bridge circuit for bidirectional motor control.
Instructions.Title: Build Motor Driver

Instructions.Description: Connect limit switches to stop motor at end positions.
Instructions.Title: Wire Limit Switch Logic

Instructions.Description: Wire LDR sensor circuit to detect daylight for automation.
Instructions.Title: Add Light Sensor

Instructions.Description: Add manual open and close buttons for override control.
Instructions.Title: Install Control Buttons

Instructions.Description: Wire indicator LEDs for open/closed status display.
Instructions.Title: Add Status LEDs

Instructions.Description: Verify curtain opens and closes smoothly with buttons.
Instructions.Title: Test Manual Control

Instructions.Description: Cover/uncover light sensor to test automatic operation.
Instructions.Title: Test Auto Mode
Instructions.Tip: Adjust LDR threshold for your lighting conditions!

Instructions.Description: Fine-tune limit switch positions and motor speed.
Instructions.Title: Final Adjustments

Title: Build an Automated Curtain Opener
LearningObjectives: Use limit switches for position sensing
FunFact: Smart curtains are part of the growing home automation market, which is expected to reach $150 billion by 2025!
